name: Urinary tract infection (recurrent): antimicrobial prescribing
rules: IF a person aged 16 years and over presents with recurrent UTI THEN consider antiseptic prophylaxis with methenamine hippurate 1 g twice a day.

IF a person aged 16 years and over presents with recurrent UTI THEN consider first-choice antibiotics: Trimethoprim 200 mg single dose when exposed to a trigger, or 100 mg nightly; Nitrofurantoin (if eGFR ≥ 45 ml/min) 100 mg single dose when exposed to a trigger, or 50 to 100 mg nightly.

IF a person aged 16 years and over presents with recurrent UTI, resistant to first-choice antibiotics THEN consider second-choice antibiotics: Amoxicillin 500 mg single dose when exposed to a trigger, or 250 mg nightly; Cefalexin 500 mg single dose when exposed to a trigger, or 125 mg nightly.
IF a child under 3 months presents with recurrent UTI THEN refer to a paediatric specialist.
IF a child aged 3 months and over presents with recurrent UTI THEN, with specialist advice, consider first-choice antibiotics: Trimethoprim, or Nitrofurantoin (if eGFR ≥ 45 ml/min).
IF a child aged 3 months and over, resistant to first-choice antibiotics THEN consider second-choice antibiotics: Cefalexin, or Amoxicillin.

nodes.text: Person aged 16 years and over presents with recurrent UTI
Consider antiseptic prophylaxis with methenamine hippurate 1 g twice a day
Consider first-choice antibiotics: Trimethoprim or Nitrofurantoin
Consider second-choice antibiotics: Amoxicillin or Cefalexin
Child under 3 months presents with recurrent UTI
Child aged 3 months and over presents with recurrent UTI
With specialist advice, consider first-choice antibiotics: Trimethoprim or Nitrofurantoin
Consider second-choice antibiotics: Cefalexin or Amoxicillin
